title: @Riot What do you guys think about Annie's ult in terms of game health.
body: Everyday I come here seeing dozens of post complaining about Annie not having enough counterplay (which honestly, I would agree), however I don't see many responses from the gameplay team. Riot as a company has been very transparent about a lot of things, which I appreciate. However, I would really like to know you guys' stance on her, and give you a chance to clear the air on this topic, so we can go back to complaining about other champs {{champion:92}} {{champion:103}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:53}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:67}}  and {{champion:92}} . Do you guys think her kit is good the way it is? Or do you think she may need some changes?

replies.body: I don't necessarily speak for the whole balance team or anything like that, but to me, Annie's ult feels somewhat like a double-edged sword as far as game health goes. On the one hand, an instant AoE stun is pretty frustrating to play against. On the other, the reliability Annie brings helps keep things like mobility creep in check.

But if we have nothing to keep mobility creep in check, perhaps that will finally force you guys to assign a power level to mobility as opposed to giving it to basically everybody new for free and saying, "Here's a counter, play it."

As far as what makes Annie different from Veigar, I believe Veigar's was longer effective range, higher stun duration, and not on an ultimate cooldown (which Annie's is if she is stunning at long range). As to why Annie is fine whereas Veigar's old stun wasn't, if it were up to me, Annie's stun (or at least her ult) would likely get the similar treatment. I'd much rather have the two spells performing in a way that left opponents with a suitable response.

>That said, learning how to hit that spell on its edge was just a matter of practice, and once it was learned, it was effectively just a 1-shot combo, and I don't think most players are really okay with the idea of someone being able to reliably 1-shot someone because they practiced.

Are you seriously telling me that because someone practiced their champion, it's unfun to see how good they are, and an Annie without any practice can effectively win every teamfight by punching their keyboard?  That doesn't make sense...


> Even well practiced champions should leave opponents with the ability to act.

Meanwhile Annie.

>As to why Annie is fine whereas Veigar's old stun wasn't, if it were up to me, Annie's stun (or at least her ult) would likely get the similar treatment. I'd much rather have the two spells performing in a way that left opponents with a suitable response.

I appreciate that.  I'm hoping I'm not coming across as attacking you, I'm just to the point where these types of explanations mean very little (save for frustration) to me when I'm thinking about everything the balance team has done, and their contradicting rational to support their idiotic decisions.

> Are you seriously telling me that because someone practiced their champion, it's unfun to see how good they are, and an Annie without any practice can effectively win every teamfight by punching their keyboard? That doesn't make sense...

It's not that they should be punished for practicing. It's that practice should not allow players to circumvent counterplay in such a manner that it leaves opponents without suitable responses. And I don't mean to be picking on practice like it's some kind of bad thing. Again, my perspective is not "Veigar was unfair, but Annie is fair" or "Veigar and Annie were both equally difficult to play." If I had to guess, I'd probably just assume that Annie hasn't gotten her change yet.

To elaborate on the point about practice, imagine we released a champion that had a 1-pixel wide instant laser skillshot that instantly killed its victim if it hit them dead in the center pixel of their hitbox, but otherwise, the caster was killed. With enough practice (and perfect ping), it's possible that someone could hit that reliably. This is somewhat hyperbolic, and Veigar's cage was nothing to this extreme, but you can still see that it's probably not safe to allow practice to reliably circumvent opponent counterplay.

In this context, wouldn't {{champion:92}}'s animation canceling somewhat run along those lines? Perfecting her animation canceling doesn't really involve much interaction with an opponent, and mastering the mechanic gives Riven much burstier damage, which gives a much smaller window of counterplay for her opponent to fight back or avoid her attacks.

CertainlyT is reading this thread.

I have to call you out on this.
There are a lot of champions, even newer ones, whose kits have tools that they can use to cover up their weaknesses and reliably circumvent opponent counterplay once practiced enough.

Yasuo is the prime example of this (he has the tools to almost completely invalidate most skillshot-based mages), but there are also plenty of others.

Kalista, Lee Sin, and Fizz are three other serious offenders.

The problem there is not with Yasuo, the problem is with skillshot mages. Skillshots in general are bad because they're spells that can be completely negated by opponents, without the caster being able to do anything about it.

There are a few ways that skillshots can be negated normally:
 1) The enemy can step to the side at the appropriate time.  This involves some amount of mind games, since the skillshot user can predict where you will dodge to and try to aim there instead.  There is room for skill on both parties here, to affect the outcome.
 2) The enemy can use a mobility spell at the appropriate time.  This is easier than stepping aside, but has the cost of using the champion's movement/escape ability (putting it on cooldown), and consuming resources (mana.)

These work perfectly in almost all cases.  The only place where it breaks down is when a champion has multiple tools to negate the skillshots, or when the tool that they have does not have enough cost in using it in this manner.

For example: It tends to feel fair when Ezreal uses his Arcane Shift to dodge a skillshot, because the skill has a huge cooldown and uses a lot of mana.
On the other hand, it feels very unfair when Kalista uses her hop to avoid a skillshot, since she didn't actually pay anything it.


Are you proposing removing skillshots entirely?
Skillshots are one of the things that really define League of Legends, and differentiate it from other MOBAs.  The game would be much less interesting and unique without them.

I'm not necessarily opposed to the idea of skill shots in general, but they are massively overused on champions in general. Having abilities that can be completely negated by my opponent is not in any way fun or interesting to me. It doesn't matter if the ability is very powerful in theory; if it can miss in a crucial moment, then that means the ability can't be counted on. I vastly prefer abilities that are reliable and always work, because those are the abilities that won't fail you in a crisis.

In particular, I do not like what skill shots have done to the game as a whole: before, on click disables or attacks were fairly commonplace, now the mere existence of such an ability causes a barrage of threads to be made (like this one) all crusading and railing about the unfairness of the abilities that auto-connect. Perhaps I would not hate them so much, if not for that fact.

You can have your skill shots, but leave my on-clicks alone.

> It's that practice should not allow players to circumvent counterplay in such a manner that it leaves opponents without suitable responses.

An Annie who has practised clicking her ult on the enemies and correctly gauging Flash + Tibbers's range does not leave the opponents with many suitable responses. Why is it acceptable that Annie has been able to do this for so long, but it is not acceptable for other champions?

Please understand: there is no suitable response to Annie revving up her stun. There is very little you can do against Annie's stun except make her click you and hope you won't die from being stunned. Could we please have more meaningful counterplay to Annie's stun? Or to Annie period. I get the argument that "Annie is necessary to keep mobility creep in check", but Annie's skillset works equally well against non-mobile champions as it does against mobile ones. I think you should keep mobility creep in check by hitting highly mobile champs rather than preserving Annie as the poster child of a kit that knows no counterplay.

If Riot had removed these instant or well practiced cc abilities years ago, players would be applauding you. Might still get some criticism though. Right now, with not only the current mobile meta, but future reworks and new champions receiving mobility, Riot needs to either rethink removing these abilities, or have a long conversation on making mobility a part of a kit. Mobility is strong, and champions should have more trade-offs for it.

I'm not sure if "helps keep things like mobility creep in check" is anything more than a band-aid here, though. Things like Annie's insta-stun aren't necessary evils as much as they are the lesser of two evils.

I hope we can agree that mobility creep here is the true problem, and the only way to truly address it is to both kick the habit of just tossing it in kits as an easy way to make them "feel better", and apply sweeping balance changes to all mobile champions that take into account the true value of mobility. 

If League remains a game that involves both prevalent mobility creep and the unhealthy countermeasures it demands, I don't think that's a game I'll want to keep playing for much longer.

> * Annie's Tibbers working like Morde's new pet Dragon.

This pet Dragon thing really was a bad idea, you know. Good on paper. **Bad in practice**.

But the problem with using instant/targeted hard CC to counter mobility creep is that it is just as effective (and often more effective) against immobile champions.

If Annie flashes towards you to use Tibbers, you can predict it and avoid it with a flash of your own - but a mobile champion can avoid it with their mobility spell.

The (limited) counterplay is the same in both cases, but the mobile champion is better at it / can do it more often than the immobile one.

Also, Annie is one champion.  You can't use the existence of one (or several) champions who counters another as justification for the second champion's power.  That's basically heading towards hard-counter matchups, which are against Riot's stated Design Goal of Counterplay (which states that no game should be decided in champion select.)

Actually that doesnt even solve most problems. We need champions that are more diverse in their niches. Kogmaw being the best artillery mage in the game shouldnt be a thing.

You can't have defined niches that matter because a champion with mobility and damage is a generalist that is just the better pick all the time. Increasing CDs doesn't matter, Annie is pretty much only good when she has Flash up and she still wins team fights. 

CDR is too free. Increase CDs and champs can still get max CDR along with mana and 160 AP for two item slots, which ends up being totally worth it for the amount of utility that mobility offers. And with most AP items only giving 100 now, double Morello doesn't even set you back that much.

Niches don't matter when a champion is safer. Harder to kill, better at kiting and chasing, and still doing damage.
